children.name: do a1
children.definition: do to do something – used in the following phrases :
examples: do do your work/homework etc:it usually takes me a couple of hours to do my homework.
do the shopping/cooking/washing etc:she’s gone to the supermarket to do the shopping.
do a test/experiment/some research:the doctor did some tests.|fraser spent some time in egypt doing some archaeological research.|scientists are doing research on two types of vaccine.|
do a test/ exam/ course etcbritishhave you decided which course you want to do at university?

children.name: make a2
children.definition: make to do something – used in the following phrases
examples: make an effort/ decision/ start/ etc
we can’t wait any longer. you need to make a decision now.
archie doesn’t even make an effort to help out around the house.
make a speech/ suggestion/ remark /complaint/ joke/ etc
at school the other kids always made jokes about my name.
i’d like to make a suggestion if that’s all right.
the governor will be making a speech here next week.

children.name: give a2
children.definition: give to do something – used in the following phrases
examples: give a talk/speech/lecture/ etc
they’ve asked him to give a talk.
mr banks gave a short talk about his travels in africa.
professor williams will be giving a series of lectures on environmental pollution.
give a performance
the band gave a brilliant performance.
davis gives a wonderful performance as an 81-year-old man.

children.name: go about x
children.definition: go about  to start or continue doing a job, especially when sth serious has happened - use this when sb does a job in their usual way, or when you are talking about the way they do it: làm
examples: the old man hummed to himself as he went about his gardening.
i’m thinking about changing careers, but i don’t quite know how to go about it.
go about doing sth
how would you go about reorganizing the kitchen?
go about your work/businesscontinue doing what you were doing or always do
the next day she went about her business as if nothing had happened.
the next morning, she went about her business as if nothing out of the ordinary had happened.

children.name: perform b2
children.definition: perform to do sth, especially sth difficult or useful.performis more formal thancarry out, and is used in the following phrases :thực hiện
examples: surgeons performed an emergency operation.
the official opening ceremony was performed by princess margaret.
registerin everyday english, people usually say that someonecarries outan operation, a study etc rather than useperform:
the operation wascarried outby a team of surgeons.
perform a task/job/duty etcwhat skills do you need to perform this task?
perform workover 6,000 people in our community of 100,000 perform volunteer work.
perform an experiment/study etcpart of the chemistry exam involves performing an experiment.
perform an operationthe surgeon who performed the operation said it had gone well.
perform a ceremonyat 3 o'clock, the opening ceremony was performed by the queen.
perform a serviceour troops are performing a remarkable service and a terribly important mission.
perform a function/rolethe two organizations perform similar functions.
perform an actionthe children sing and perform the actions to nursery songs.
perform miracles(= do things that seem impossible )i'm prepared to work hard to get the job done but i can't perform miracles.

children.name: conduct b2
children.definition: conduct to carry out a particular activity or process, especially in order to get information or prove facts – used in the following phrases : thực hiện, tiến hành
examples: it was the first time that i had conducted business in brazil.
registerin everyday english, people usually saydoorcarry outrather thanconduct:
they’redoinga survey of opinions about organic food.
conduct researchhe’s conducting educational research at the university of washington.
conduct a surveythey conducted a survey of students’ careers one year after graduation.
conduct a study/reviewscientists conducted a study of the area affected by the nuclear disaster.
conduct an investigation/inquiryexperts conducted an investigation into the causes of the crash.
conduct an interviewhere are a few guidelines on how to conduct an interview.
conduct a campaignthe party was criticized for the way it had conducted its election campaign.
conduct a test/experimentinvestigators will be conducting tests to determine how the man died.
conduct a searchthe spanish authorities conducted a nationwide search for the girl.
conduct (a) businessthe company had been conducting a lot of business in latin america.

children.name: dabble in x
children.definition: dabble in to do something that you are interested in or enjoy, but not very often or regularly, or not in a very serious way: học đòi, “nhúng vào nước”
examples: when he was younger he used to dabble in astronomy.
beck has dabbled in poetry over the years, but this is her first published book of poems.

children.name: take b1
children.definition: take to do something – used in the following phrases :
examples: take a test/exam:kate’s taking her driving test tomorrow.
take a bath/shower:i think i’ll go and take a shower.
take a walk:normally, he took a walk in the evenings.

children.name: have a2
children.definition: havebritish englishto do something
examples: have a look/walk/sleep/talk/think etc
we were just having a look around.
are you going to have a swim?

children.name: to do sth has already been planned or ordered
carry out b1
children.definition: carry out sth– used in the following phrases
examples: 1to do something that needs to be organized and planned : thực hiện, tiến hành
we need to carry out more research.
a survey is now being carried out nationwide.
turn off the water supply before carrying out repairs.
registerin written english, people often useconductwhen writing about research, experiments etc, because this sounds more formal thancarry out:
theyconductedexperiments to test this theory.
carry out workyou’ll have to get a builder to carry out the work.
carry out your duties/responsibilitiesshe carried out her duties very efficiently.
carry out a task/jobhe was unable to carry out simple tasks.
carry out researchi was in italy carrying out research for my book.
carry out a surveythe committee has carried out a survey of parking problems in residential areas.
carry out a checkmanufacturers carry out safety checks on all new cars.
carry out a testforensic experts are now carrying out dna tests.
carry out an experimentmany schools need better facilities for carrying out scientific experiments.
carry out a reviewthe government is carrying out a review of state pension provision.
carry out a studyhe has carried out various studies into violent behaviour.
carry out an investigationthe police will carry out an investigation into what actually happened.
carry out an inquirya formal inquiry into the cause of death will be carried out.
carry out an assessmentthe company is carrying out an assessment of staff training needs.
carry out a searchhere are some more ways of carrying out information searches online.
carry out an attackit became clear that terrorists had carried out the attack.
2to do sth that you have said you will do or that sb has asked you to do : thực hiện
carry out sb’s orders/ instructions/ wishes
if my instructions had been carried out, the accident would not have happened.
we carried out her instructions precisely.
carry out a threat/ promise
the terrorists carried out their threat and shot two of the hostages.
will the government carry out its promise to reform the law?
nicholson didn’t carry out his threat to take legal action.

children.name: execute c2
children.definition: execute formal to do sth that you have carefully planned or that you have agreed to do - used especially in official, legal, or business contexts: chạy, tiến hành, thực hiện
examples: ▪ we will not be able to execute the programs without more funding.
▪ the directors make the decisions, but it’s the managers who have to execute them.
▪ the goal of landing people on mars will not be an easy one to execute.
execution[u]
▪ the department is responsible for the planning and execution of military operations.

children.name: implement b2
children.definition: implement formal to do sth after an official decision has been made that it should be done: thi hành, thực hiện
examples: implement a plan/aproposal/ recommendations/ policy etc
▪ we need a strategy that can be implemented quickly.
▪ very few parties in government ever want to implement major political reform.
▪ an international team has been set up to implement recent un recommendations
implementation[u] c2
▪ a clear timetable for the implementation of new city programs is lacking.

children.name: put sth into practice b2
children.definition: put sth into practice if you put an idea or sth you have learned into practice, you use it in your work or in your life, and you find out if it is effective: đưa vào thực tiễn, thực hiện
examples: the office has been slow to put the new proposals into practice.
a lot of these modern theories about teaching sound really good until you actually try and put them into practice.

children.name: deliver the goods x
children.definition: deliver the goods/ come up with the goods informal to successfully do what other people have asked you to do or expect you to do - used especially in business: thực hiện cam kết
examples: ▪ what the country needs is an economic and political system capable of delivering the goods.
▪ when the company’s director failed to come up with the goods, he was out.

children.name: to do sth after a delay or pause
get on with x
children.definition: get on with especially uk, spoken to start doing something that you should have started already, or continue doing something that you have stopped doing for a short time: tiếp tục
examples: i’m glad the guests are gone so i can get on with my work.
heavy rain is preventing rescue teams from getting on with the search.
get on with it
stop messing around - just get on with it!

children.name: get around to n
children.definition: get around toalsoget round touk  to finally do sth that you have been intending to do for a long time, but have been too busy or too lazy to do:
examples: i was going to fill out an application, but i never got around to it.
get around/ round to doing sth
i must get round to painting the kitchen some day

children.name: get going c2
children.definition: get going spoken to start doing sth, especially when you should have started already:
examples: we’ve got so much to do - let’s get going.
get going on
you need to get going on that report. it’s due tomorrow.

children.name: to do sth that is bad or wrong
be up to b1
children.definition: be up to sth informal if sb is up to sth they are probably doing sth bad, but you do not know exactly what :
examples: i know he’s lying - what do you think he’s up to?
the kids have been whispering and giggling all day - i think they’re up to something.
be up to no goodbe doing sth bad
she was beginning to suspect that the handsome stranger was up to no good.

children.name: get up to c2
children.definition: get up to sth uk to do sth that other people disapprove of, especially because you think it is funny or because you enjoy it: giở mấy trò, làm cái trò
examples: she peeped into the bedroom to see what her mischief grandson was getting up to.
when we were students, we used to get up to all sorts of things.

children.name: commit b2
children.definition: commit/kəˈmɪt/  to do something that is a crime, especially a serious crime:
examples: commit a crime/ murder/ robbery etc
▪ women commit far fewer crimes than men.
▪ the murder must have been committed between 7 and 10pm

children.name: indulge in c2
children.definition: indulge in to do sth that you enjoy, even though there is a reason you should not do it: “nuông chiều, thỏa mãn” xả láng
examples: i was downtown, so i decided to indulge in a little shopping.
most people indulge in harmless fantasies to relieve the boredom of their lives.

children.name: stoop to x
children.definition: stoop to sth to do sth that you know is morally wrong because you think it is the only way that you can achieve what you want to achieve: “hèn hạ”
examples: ‘she even tried to get him fired.’ ‘i can’t believe she’d stoop to that.’
stoop to doing sth
they ended up stooping to hair-pulling and name-calling.
his lawyers even stooped to using the children to gain public sympathy.

children.name: ways of asking what sb is doing
what is sb doing?
children.definition: what is somebody doing? /ˌwɒt ɪz somebody ˈduːɪŋ/ spoken:
examples: ▪ what are you two doing?
▪ he’s been in the yard a long time - what’s he doing out there?

children.name: what is sb up to?
children.definition: what is somebody up to?/ˌwɒt ɪz somebody ˈʌp tuː/spokensay this when you think someone is secretly doing somethingbad:
examples: bạn đang âm mưu gì thế ( đang bí mật làm gì xấu)
▪ you look guilty, stuart. what have you been up to?
trông anh đáng nghi quá , stuart. anh đang âm mưu gì thế ?
▪ they’ve been locked in there all morning - what are they up to?
họ đã khóa cửa bên trong cả buổi sáng - họ đang âm mưu gì không biết ?

children.name: what is sb playing at?
children.definition: what is somebody playing at?/ˌwɒt ɪz somebody ˈpleɪ-ɪŋ æt/ british spoken say this when you are angry and think someone has done something wrong or stupid:
examples: ai đó đang làm trò gì thế?
▪ she shouldn’t have told him what i said. what was she playing at?
cô ta không nên nói lại lời tôi với anh ấy- cô ta đang làm trò gì thế?
▪ you boys! what on earth do you think you’re playing at? stop it at once!
các cậu! các cậu nghĩ mình đang làm trò gì thế này? dừng lại ngay!

children.name: active b1
children.definition: active always doing things or ready to do things, especially physical activities or activities within an organization:
examples: ▪ they’re both in their seventies, but they’re still very active.
active in
▪ in washington harriman quickly became active in democratic party affairs
active member
▪ today there are over 5,000 active members in the accra church.

children.name: in action b2
children.definition: in action if you see sb in action, you see them doing the job or activity that they are trained to do or usually do:
examples: ▪ i’ve heard a lot about his dancing - i’d love to see him in action.
▪ the advertisement shows two firefighters in action putting out a blaze.
▪ i had seen him in action during the san josé strike, and i was very impressed.

children.name: thing a1
children.definition: thing sth that sb does - always use this with the verb do:
examples: the first thing you should do is connect the printer to the computer.
a nice/ stupid/ nasty etc thing to do
that was a really nice thing to do - i know leona enjoys your visits.
i know i shouldn’t have hit him - it was a dumb thing to do.
the right/ best/ smart/ only etc thing to do
he gave her half the money because it was the right thing to do.

children.name: action b2
children.definition: action something that someone does
examples: quick/swift/prompt action
herprompt actionsprobably saved my life.
the child could not beheld responsible for his actions(= he was too young to be blamed for them ).
defend/justify your action(s)
the chief of police tried to justify his actions.

children.name: activities b2
children.definition: activities things that people do to achieve an aim, especially as an organized group - use this especially about illegal things that people do : các hoạt động
examples: the fbi is investigating the company’s business activities.
there is growing evidence of drug-smuggling activities in and around the port.
alberts created false documents to hide his activities from his employers.
engage in an activityformal(= take part )police suspect he may have engaged in criminal activities.
be involved in an activitythe men were involved in terrorist activities.
criminal/illegal activitythe bar was being used for illegal activities.
terrorist activitythe police took extra measures to protect the public against terrorist activity.

children.name: activity b1
children.definition: activity the situation in which a lot of things are happening or people are moving around: hoạt động
examples: there’s a lot of activity downstairs - do you know what’s going on?
military activity was secretly taking place for weeks before the invasion.
the office was suddenly full offrantic activity.
the farm was alwaysa hive of activityat this time of year.
there was a lot of activity in preparation for the queen's visit.
flurry of activity
there was a sudden flurry of activity when the director walked in.
political activitypolitical activity is closely controlled by the government.
economic activitythe current level of economic activity will influence business confidence.
economists are concerned by the low level of economic activity.
business/commercial activityinternet shopping is a rapidly developing area of business activity.
human activitythere was no sign of any human activity.
the level of activitythe level of economic activity has increased.

children.name: act b2
children.definition: act a particular type of action :
examples: i believe the killing was an act of desperation.
the new president’s first act should be to end the war.
a thoughtless act
act of (doing) something
an act of violence
her many acts of kindness
the act of writing a list can help to calm you down.
in the act of doing something(= at the moment that you are doing something )
lindsay paused in the act of putting down the phone.
registerin everyday english, people usually saya thoughtless/kind/stupid etc thing to dorather thana thoughtless/kind/stupid etc act.
an act of violence/aggressionincidents of sexual harassment and acts of violence against women were on the increase.
an act of kindness/lovewe were grateful for her act of kindness.
an act of faith(= when you do something that shows you trust someone completely )the signing of the treaty with britain was an act of faith.
an act of terrorism(= when someone kills people or bombs a place for political reasons )it was the worst act of terrorism in us history.
an act of vandalism(= when someone deliberately damages things, especially public property )these mindless acts of vandalism affect the whole community.
an act of defiance(= when you refuse to obey or respect someone )as an act of defiance leigh dropped out of high school a month before graduation.
an act of courage/braverythe men were awarded the medals for acts of courage.
a criminal/illegal/unlawful actstarting the fire was a highly irresponsible criminal act.
a violent/aggressive actwe will track down those responsible for this violent act.
terrorist actsterrorists acts like the oklahoma city bombing
a cowardly act(= not at all brave )the united states strongly condemns this cowardly act by murderous extremists.
a heroic act(= very brave )ordinary people sometimes find themselves performing heroic acts.
a deliberate/conscious actclearly this was a deliberate act of vandalism.
a symbolic act(= something you do to express an idea or feeling )the tibetan climber will pass the olympic flame to his chinese partner in a symbolic act of friendship.
commit an actformal(= do something wrong or illegal )anyone committing an illegal act deserves to be punished.
perform an act(= do something, especially something difficult or useful )the nurses performed many small acts of kindness.

children.name: deed x
children.definition: deedespecially literaryan action, especially one that is very good or very bad : nghĩa cử, hành vi
examples: evil/ heroic deed
one day he will pay for his evil deeds.
she tried to strangle her baby and her lover helped her finish the evil deed .
he grew up reading the tales and legends of heroic deeds.
good deed
this is my good deed for the day .
well, that’s my good deed for the day.

children.name: feat c2
children.definition: feat sth that is an impressive achievement, because it needs a lot of skill, strength etc to do : kỳ công, chiến công
examples: remarkable/considerable/incredible etc feat
they climbed the mountain in 28 days, a remarkable feat.
feat of
an incredible feat of engineering
perform/accomplish/achieve a feat
the woman who performed the feat of sailing around the world alone
no mean feat(= something that is difficult to do )
it is no mean feat to perform such a difficult piece.

children.name: exploits x
children.definition: exploitsformalbrave or exciting actions that people are told about and admire: kỳ công, chiến công
examples: the children loved to hear their father tell stories of his wartime exploits.
powell’s exploits on the colorado river made him a hero of the old west.
his exploits were legendary.

children.name: action c2
children.definition: actionnounsomething done
examples: [ c ] a physical movement
_i'll say the words and you can mime the actions.
_it only needs a small wrist action (= movement of the wrist) to start the process.

children.name: operation c1
children.definition: operationnounwork
examples: [ c ] an activity which is planned to achieve something
_a military/peacekeeping operation.
_following the earthquake, a large-scalerescueoperation waslaunched.
_[ + to infinitive ]the operationtofly in supplies will begin as soon as possible.

children.name: operator b2
children.definition: operatornoun
examples: someone whose job is to use and control a machine or vehicle
_a computer operator

children.name: performance b2
children.definition: performancenoundo
examples: [ c or u ] how well a person, machine, etc. does a piece of work or an activity
_some athletes take drugs to improve their performance.
_high-performance (= fast, powerful and easy to control) cars are the most expensive.
_this was a veryimpressiveperformance by the young player, who scored 12 points within the first 10 minutes.

children.name: practice b2
children.definition: practicenounaction
examples: [ u ] action rather than thought or ideas
_it seemed like a good idea before we started, butinpractice it was a disaster.
_officially, robert's in charge, butinpractice hannah runs the office.
_i can't see how your planis going to workinpractice.
_how do you intend toputthese proposalsintopractice, mohamed?

children.name: undertake c1
children.definition: undertakeverbundertook,undertakendo
examples: slightly formalto do or begin to do something, especially something that will take a long time or be difficult
_students are required to undertake simple experiments.

children.name: exercise c2
children.definition: exercisenounpractice
examples: [ c ] an action or actions intended to improve something or make something happen
_ships from eight navies will be taking part in an exercise in the pacific to improve their efficiency in combat.
_it would be a useful exercise for you to say the speech aloud several times. an exerciseinpublic relations

children.name: get round to b2
children.definition: get round tosthphrasal verbuk
examples: to do something that you have
intended to do for a long time
_i still haven't got round to fixing that tap.

children.name: go through with c2
children.definition: go through withsthphrasal verb
examples: to do something unpleasant or difficult that
has already been agreed or promised
_he'd threatened to divorce her but i
never thought he'd go through with it.
_the company has decided not to go
through with the takeover of its smaller rival.

children.name: initiative c1
children.definition: initiative an important new plan or process to achieve a particular aim or to solve a particular problem : sáng kiến
examples: a government initiative to help exporters
an education initiative
thepeaceinitiative was welcomed by both sides.
initiative for
a new initiative for peace in the middle east
